events.name: Android SDK and our First Group Challenge
events.description: Learn more about one of the best mobile development platforms and help us contextualize and take on our first public challenge. Remember to sign up with your full name so we can make you a badge. See you at Google!

events.name: Google Cloud Platform and Android Development with Ruby
events.description:
Speakers:

Robert Kluin - Rapid prototyping on Google Cloud Platform
The talk will demonstrate using Google Cloud Platform to rapidly build prototypes of ideas.  The prototype will highlight the key strengths of App Engine, Cloud Storage, and Compute Engine. 

Patrick Martin - Unity and how it's Changing Mobile
Primarily a video game development engine, Unity has shaken the mobile development world by bringing a stable, professional development environment that can deploy a single product to multiple platforms, including Android, iOS, Windows, Mac, and even Xbox and Playstation! The results are consistent across the platforms and relatively painless. For this reason, many developers have been adopting it for uses outside of video games.

Remember to register with your full name.

events.name: Monthly Meetup - GovDev Discussion
events.description: We'll have speakers lined up as well, let us know what aspect of Google Development you'd like to learn more about in the comment section.

events.name: Google GovDev Challenge
events.description: We've talked about it for months, now its time to put our development skills to work for our community. Help improve local government and compete for great prizes. Register today and lets get started! http://www.govdevchallenge.com/

events.name: Presentations and Congrats to our GovDev Champs!
Meetup - Lightning Talks & I/O Show and Tell
events.description:
We'll be having two exciting lightning talks on:

1. Go (the language)
2. SendGrid's partnership with Google.

and we'll be doing a Google I/O show and tell.  

Bring any gear + swag you picked up at Google I/O, as well as your thoughts on what excited you most about any I/O announcements.

events.name: Is Thought the Future of Wearable Input?
events.description:
Demo: Brain-controlled quadcopter!

Jim McKeeth will be coming to speak about Wearable EEG's and what they can offer us now and in the future.

Jim is the Lead Developer Evangelist at Embarcadero Technologies﻿

Agenda:

1. Building a shared UI for iOS and Android for rapid prototyping. 

2. Android and the Brain-Computer Interface

The Brain-Computer Interface is a mainstay of science fiction, and devices are available today to use our brainwaves as input for mobile devices. But is it practical? How far away is it? Will "Big Brother" read our thoughts and hack our brains? 

In this part, we will dive into the future of thought as input for wearable devices with real-world examples and code. Demonstrations will be shown using the Emotiv EPOC headset, a high resolution, neuro-signal acquisition and processing wireless neuroheadset that uses a set of sensors to tune into electric signals produced by the brain to detect thoughts, feelings and expressions. This device is about to be superseded by a new generation of neuroheadsets that interface directly with Android devices via Bluetooth.  You will see the EEG neuroheadset and brain-computer interface with examples of interfacing with desktop, mobile and wearable apps. A volunteer will use the headset and some custom software to control a Parrot AR.Drone quadricopter.

We will dive into the roots of the technology, showing code and examples along with big pictures of the technology. You will walk away with an understanding of how this still evolving and largely unknown technology really works, how it can be used, as well as longer-term implications.

(Pushed one week earlier)

events.name: DevFest Colorado
events.description:
Connect with developers, designers, entrepreneurs, teachers and students.

Each Google Developer Group DevFest is inspired by and uniquely tailored to the needs of the developer community that hosts it. This year the GDG's in Colorado are getting together to host one at the Google offices in Boulder, CO. Yay!

We're getting together to push tech forward in Colorado with one of the latest Google technologies, Android Wear.

We'll host a full day Android Wear Hack-a-thon on November 1st from 10:00AM to 6PM.

Make sure to register through the official site. And let us know if you have any questions. We look forward to seeing everybody there!

This year the hackathon will center the latest in Andriod Wear
events.how_to_find_us: Google Boulder is located right near Hazel's off 28th St.

events.name: Android Hack Night
events.description:
=== Date & time change: Now on January 15 at 6pm ===

Android Hack Night is for everyone who's interested in Android programming. If you...

• Have no Android experience
Install Android Studio on your laptop and we'll walk through Hello World together. http://developer.android.com/sdk

• Just got started but not sure what to do next
Follow the Udacity course and bring your questions. https://www.udacity.com/course/ud853

• Tinker with Android as your side project
Bring your project, share what's working and where the pain points are.

• Live and breathe Android
Come help others, or, if you are brave, there will be a coding challenge where you write an app on the spot and present your solution.

We will all be coding, so don't forget your laptops, chargers, Android devices and USB cables!

events.name: Intro to Google App Engine
events.description:
Get started with App Engine with this Intro to App Engine session!  

Bring your laptop and we will step you through an intro application.  In preparation for the session, we ask you take a look at this preliminary doc to install App Engine on your machine (a very straightforward process).

Look forward to seeing you all!

events.name: You Can Be a Data Scientist Using Just Spreadsheets (Yes, Really!)
events.description:
Do you ever feel like you could just order a side of Hadoop with your Cassandra and enjoy it on your CouchDB? The tools are everywhere. The ability to use them is hard to come by. Here are some simple and basic techniques to help drive process improvement for your organization.

Speaker: Stacey Schipper

Stacey is an Analyst in human services where she spends her time coaxing data into a usable format and trying to stop the tools from wagging the analytics. With a complimentary Ellie’s Brown Ale Stacey she can generate quick, reliable and easy to use information. When she’s away from the computer you can probably find her up a mountain. 

Agenda:

6:45pm Talk starts
7:45pm Talk ends
8:00pm Door closes

https://plus.google.com/events/cgrute825m3sv909nd0da0if0ag

Note: Do not RSVP here.

events.name: Android Camera2 API
events.description:
One of many notable additions and upgrades in Android Lollipop, Camera 2 is a significant re-work of the Android's interface with camera devices that includes a pipelined implementation, a unified model and method for building and making still and video requests, much wider support for manual controls (on supported devices), detailed metadata at all stages, and more output options. At the same time, the Camera 2 API is significantly more complex and requires more care, coordination, and asynchronous work.

The goal of this talk is to provide a starting point for developers interested in leveraging Camera 2, providing an overview of Camera 2's structure and how to get started, examining the challenges and possibilities.

events.name: Bugdroid Style
events.description:
Mike Wolfson, Android GDE from Phoenix (and Denver Native), will talk about styling Android effectively.

---

It has always been challenging to chase Android fashion. For many years, the “style-makers” were pushing designs that would look more appropriate on an iPhone, or that were beautiful and unique masterpieces, yet impossible to actually implement. This was compounded by the fact that the formal guidelines were unclear, and incomplete. This made the role of an Android Interface developer very challenging.

In recent years, I have participated in many high-profile “UI refresh” projects. I have learned a lot from these projects, and will share a few key lessons I have learned from this practical experience.

I will discuss: 

• how to build beautiful interfaces that are universally styled, responsive and beautiful 

• strategies to work with designers and stake-holders to enhance workflow

• the important concepts of the new ‘Material Design Guidelines'

• leveraging the support libraries to build compliant apps 

Come to this presentation to learn the techniques you will need to be ready for the next Android fashion fad. 

“Fashions fade, style is eternal.” — Yves Saint-Laurent

Slides: http://tiny.cc/gdgboulderjuly2015

events.name: Google Solutions for Lean Analytics
events.description: Building a smarter, faster company means using the right tools to gather the right information. This meeting will cover several Google tools like AdWords, Analytics, and Google my Business that can help any company go lean.

events.name: The Integration of Things
events.description:
Jordan Stone of Denver based Notion (http://getnotion.com/) will be talking with us about developing in the IOT space for Nest integration.

Notion is a Denver-based Internet of Things company and Techstars Boulder graduate. Two of Notion's own, Jordan Stone and Shelby Switzer, will discuss the process they went through building a connected device and the challenges (and opportunity) they found integrating it with other platforms like "Works with Nest"

events.name: Family DevFest
events.description:
Our annual Google Developer Group DevFest event! It is a family themed event this year, brought to you by GDG Boulder, GDG Denver and GDG Northern Colorado.

We are also inviting kids at heart that can act as mentors, coaches and volunteers.

Register here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/colorado-devfest-2015-family-edition-tickets-18271593829

We expect this event to sell out, so grab a ticket as soon as you can.

Hope to see you at DevFest! 

Note: We are using EventBrite to co-ordinate event registration among the 3 GDGs, so remember to get a ticket via the EventBrite. RSVP to this meetup page doesn't count.

events.name: Model View Presenter for Android
events.description: When testing your app it can be hard when most of the code deals with setting your views from lifecycle objects. Learn how to encapsulate your view management code in a way that encourages testing and declutters your Activities and Fragments.

events.name: Google Tensorflow
events.description: This is a first meetup to see who is interested in Tensorflow and to have a discussion on a potential project we can work through over a series of meetups.

We're going to be limited on space so only RSVP if you're fairly certain to make it. :)

events.name: Google I/O Extended - Boulder
events.description:
Google I/O is right around the corner! Sign up for limited following the link below. Remember, RSVPing on meetup alone won't be enough! Space is limited, so make sure to sign up before Thursday, April 28th.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/16i2_nELuSD5-GZGtVRNY5VsglIta9xxTPA5ki4qbdBY/viewform

We look forward to seeing your there!

You don't need to be at Google I/O to have a front seat to the world’s latest and greatest technologies. Google is hosting a series of I/O Extended events at our offices across North America on Wednesday, May 18th where we’ll be streaming the keynote and other top sessions. Attendees can network with other talented developers and Google engineers, learn about new technologies, and experience live demonstrations of products built in our local offices. There will also be plenty of food, beverages and swag for giveaway.

Click here to sign up to be invited to I/O Extended Boulder. *Please note- this is an interest sign up to I/O Extended and does not guarantee you a spot. If selected to attend, you will receive the invite in order to RSVP for this event.*

We hope to see you there! If you have any further questions, please reach out to us at [masked].

events.name: Effective Unit Testing with Test Doubles
events.description:
A test double is any object that takes the place of a real object in a test, just like a stunt double takes the place of an actor in a movie. There are several types of test doubles, including stubs, fakes, dummies, mocks, and spies. In this talk, we'll explore the common uses of these types of test doubles, their advantages and pitfalls, and best practices for using test doubles to write effective and reliable unit tests.

All of the examples will use Java (with maybe a bit of Android!), but this talk should be relevant to all software developers.

We will be raffling a ticket to 360|AnDev, the first Android conference in Colorado: 360andev.com

events.name: Android: Optimizing & Profiling UI Performance
events.description:
Performance matters if you want to be able to provide buttery smooth, exceptional user experiences. However, it can sometimes be difficult to track down and fix these issues. In this talk you'll learn what causes jank (dropped frames) to occur while scrolling, tips on how to avoid it in the first place, and lastly how to profile for problem areas if it does happen to you.

This is a preview version of the 360|AnDev talk:
http://360andev.com/sessions/100-optimizing-and-profiling-ui-performance/

events.name: Kotlin for Android
events.description: Android is getting support for java 8 features soon, but is it enough? What's all of the fuss about Kotlin? Come learn about what Kotlin can do for android. We'll learn about how we can leverage Kotlin's modern language features to write cleaner, faster and more concise code.

events.name: GDG DevFest Family Edition at Google Boulder
events.description:
This event will require a ticket through EventBrite.

You can see pictures from last year here.

This is going to be a great event this year. We have an awesome robotics partner and a beverage sponsor too, also PWA, sparkfun, Google cardboard and other stations. 

It's also going to be an excellent chance to meet developers working on incredible projects all over The Front Range. 

Space is very limited so make sure to get your ticket today! RSVPing here won't be enough, head on over to our EventBrite page to secure your space!

events.name: Intro to RxJava for Android
events.description:
***Update***

Good news! RxJava 2.0 has officially released today. I will be covering this version in my presenatation as 2.0 fixes alot of issues with 1.X

https://github.com/ReactiveX/RxJava

RxJava is a reactive library that helps ease many pains from Android involving async calls and threading. I will be going over what is RxJava and how you can greatly benefit from it. At the end of the presentation, I will be providing additional resources to continue where I leave off in this intro. 

For people who have some experience with RxJava, if there is anything specific you would like me to cover, please leave a comment and I'll try to cover it during my talk.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1_2NjIDzyfB-BH5tCFiwltRpDkRVSPFc6oRbul0OErEc/edit?usp=sharing

events.name: Bazel is Google's own build tool, now publicly available in Beta
events.description:
In this meetup we'll cover "Bazel", google's open source version of their internal build tool "Blaze".  This is a ployglot build system used to build a number of open source projects including Tensorflow.

I'll cover bazel concepts, how to get started, and language-specific rules for java, c++, and golang.   For a demo I'll show how to build containerized gRPC applications.

Email me with suggested foci if interested beforehand.

Paul "%s@%s.%s" % ("pcj", "pubref", "org")

events.name: Firebase Android dive
events.description:
Although Firebase has been around for some time, it received a massive overhaul recently and was reintroduced to the development community during Google's I/O conference. Firebase is a service from Google that provides multiple features for developers so that they can easily put together a backend for their apps and web pages, and interact with their users. 

In this meetup you will be introduced to what Firebase has available, such as the real-time NoSQL database, analytics, crash reporting and storage, and will learn how to start using these tools in Android so that you can get up and running with your own Firebase supported applications.

Slides: https://goo.gl/FwzrrS

Demo project: https://github.com/PaulTR/GDGBoulder-Firebase-Example

events.name: Simple, Secure IoT with Google
events.description:
Google's IoT solutions make it easy for developers to build smart connected devices. They enable device makers to produce products that are secure by default, but also easy to update and maintain at scale. In this talk, we will focus on Android Things and Weave. You will learn about the role of each platform, how they are architected, and how you can get started with development.

Dave Smith is a Developer Advocate for IoT at Google, focused on growing developer support on the Android Things platform. Dave has been working with the Android stack at all levels since 2009, developing custom applications and system components to run Android on embedded platforms or interact with external embedded devices. He has a passion for making things smart, whether that be devices or his fellow developers.

events.how_to_find_us: We will be in the room "Boulder Theater", in the building at the SE corner of Pearl and 26th

events.name: Google I/O Extended 2017 - Boulder
events.description:
Please read carefully! Registration is now closed. Space will be limited and RSVPing on meetup will not guarantee you a spot. 

Thank you to everyone who got in touch regarding this great event. 

This event will only be open to people who have received verification by email from Google. There was an outpouring of interest about this event and a large number of people put forward their names for consideration. We're truly sorry we could only accommodate some of you.

I/O Extended events bring local developer communities together to experience the I/O keynote and sessions with one another in real-time, around the globe. They may also offer unique activities such as hackathons, codelabs, and demos.

GDG Boulder has been coordinating with Google to offer I/O Extended access to our community for several years and look forward to bringing together local Front Range developers for this exciting event. It's also Boulder Startup week, so plan a full day of great events. https://boulderstartupweek.com/

events.name: Design Patterns in the Light of Lambda Expressions
events.description:
Design patterns are common place in OO programming. With the introduction of lambda expressions in languages like Java, one has to wonder about their influence on design patterns. In this presentation we will take up some of the common design patterns and rework them using lambda expressions. We will also explore some other patterns that are not so common, but are quite useful ways to apply lambdas.

Bio

Dr. Venkat Subramaniam is an award-winning author, founder of Agile Developer, Inc., creator of agilelearner.com, and an instructional professor at the University of Houston.He has trained and mentored thousands of software developers in the US, Canada, Europe, and Asia, and is a regularly-invited speaker at several international conferences. Venkat helps his clients effectively apply and succeed with sustainable agile practices on their software projects.

Venkat is a (co)author of multiple technical books, including the 2007 Jolt Productivity award winning book Practices of an Agile Developer. You can find a list of his books at agiledeveloper.com. You can reach him by email at [masked] or on twitter at @venkat_s.

Note: This event is at Galvanize Boulder, not the Google office.

events.name: RxJava Pair Programming
events.description: A lot of RxJava talks and tutorial focuses on its various operators, but for beginners it can be difficult to come up with the streams to operate on. In this pair programming session, Sarah Lensing & Chiu-Ki Chan are going to work through an Android app and reason through how to convert it to RxJava. The focus will be on how to come up with a mental model to express the logic we need in the Android app.
events.how_to_find_us: Boulder Theater, across the street from the building with receiption

events.name: The Iron Data Challenge - GDG Boulder DevFest 2017
events.description:
GDG DevFest 2017 is our annual all-day developer conference that offers speaker sessions across multiple product areas, codelabs, hackathons and more!

GDG Boulder is proud to announce that the  our inaugural DevFest will take the shape of The Iron Data Challenge! Participants will be presented with three secret data ingredients and will have a limited amount of time to use at least two of them and their best data visualization and analytical tools to make something brilliant.

It could be any kind of data!

Octopus Data!

Vegetable Data!

Median Income Data!


What will you create? Whose regressions will be the meanest? Whose Correlations will be coefficient? Can you trust your K-Nearest Neighbor? Or will you strike out on your own? Which team will be crowned The 2017 Iron Analysts? 

Join GDG Boulder this October to find out!

Register now by signing up for the meetup!

Agenda

9:00 - Doors open

9:15 - Introduction - Team Creation - Data distribution

9:30 - 10:15 - Seaborn Tutorial

10:15 - 1:00 Free Coding

1:00 - Lunch 

4:00 Project Turn In

4:45 Prizes and Judging

Prizes will include four GDG refrigerators, a sweet trophy, and eternal glory as the 2017 Iron Analyst!

events.name: Google Cloud OnBoard [Takeover]
events.description:
[This is a Google event. Please register on their site instead of RSVP here.]

Welcome to Cloud OnBoard in Denver on Nov 9! Our instructors lead in-depth technical presentations and demonstrations to help you learn industry best practices and tips. Google Cloud Platform training accelerates your understanding of and ability to use the Google Cloud Platform services.

Register for free at https://cloudplatformonline.com/2017-Onboard-Northam.html

Who should attend?

Solution ArchitectsSoftware DevelopersSysOp AdministratorsExecutives and business decision makers evaluating the potential of GCP to address business needs are always welcome.

What will be covered?

Container, App and Compute EnginesMachine Learning and AIStorage

At the event's conclusion, you'll have the opportunity to attend a Q&A session with the GCP team and collect your certificate of participation.

events.name: Sketchnoting for All
events.description:
~ Partner event with Women Who Code ~

Sketchnoting is great for taking memorable notes. But most people don't think of trying it, because they claim they cannot draw. Turns out sketchnoting is not about drawing! It’s about active listening and recording with a visual vocabulary. Everyone can do it after some practice.

In this hands-on workshop you will learn the basic building blocks for sketchnoting:

• Letter styles

• Boxes, bubbles and ribbons

• Fun bullet points

After we practiced copying the visual vocabulary, you will put them in use, sketchnoting while I go through a few tips and tricks. At the end of the workshop you will have a sketchnote to remind you your new visual note taking skills.

See sketchnotes made by others at the workshop:
https://twitter.com/search?q=%23Sketchnoting4All

Tweet yours with the hashtag #Sketchnoting4all! You may want to download CamScanner to digitalize your sketchnotes:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.intsig.camscanner
https://itunes.apple.com/bf/app/camscanner/id388627783

A recorded version of this workshop is available at: https://gum.co/sketchnoting4all

Agenda

6:30 Door opens. Network, browse notebooks with sketchnotes by Chiu-Ki.
7:00 Workshop starts.
7:45 Workshop ends. Look at each other's sketchnotes, post on twitter.
8:15 Door closes.

events.name: Android Dagger Therapy Session
events.description:
Worried about getting stabbed by dagger? Dependency Injection sounds great but it can feel like so much work to implement and maintain. Let's take some of the edge off that blade and talk about how to quickly get started with dependency injection on Android using Dagger 2. In this talk we'll explore the object graph, scopes, the latest Android injection tools, and what to do about that pesky Android lifecycle.

We'll be raffling off a Daydream VR Viewer. Check to see if your phone is compatible: https://vr.google.com/daydream/smartphonevr/phones/
events.how_to_find_us: Rocky Mountain National Park (RMNP) tech talk

events.name: From Compute to Machine Learning on The Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
• What we'll do
Join us for a discussion about server-less development on The Google Cloud Platform, which will take us from Computing to Data Management to Machine Learning by Ray Tsang.

It's a great time to be a developer because we are empowered to write software which touches the whole world. By focusing on solving end-user problems, our work can address enormously complex challenges. Do do this, we have to be solution driven, focused on the core business, and able to iterate fast to produce code that differentiates itself from others.

Today, we have the power of massive data centers around the world at our finger tips, but many developers are still dealing with local machine problems! What does the world look like if you don't need to directly interact with individual machines? What can be accomplished without having to lay a keystroke in a remote server shell? What type of software and features can you deliver if you don't have to write all the backends yourself?

This session will demonstrate what technologies on the Google Cloud Platform bring to the table. We'll journey from compute to Machine Learning at scale. Prepare to be amazed, the future is here!

• What to bring

• Important to know

events.name: What the Heck is OAuth and Open ID Connect?
events.description:
• What we'll do
OAuth is not an API or a service: it is an open standard for authorization and any developer can implement it. OAuth is a standard that applications can use to provide client applications with “secure delegated access”. OAuth works over HTTP and authorizes Devices, APIs, Servers and Applications with access tokens rather than credentials, which we will go over in depth below. OpenID Connect (OIDC) is built on top of the OAuth 2.0 protocol. It allows clients to verify the identity of the user and, as well as to obtain their basic profile information.

This session covers how OAuth/OIDC works, when to use them, and frameworks/services that simplify authentication.

Matt Raible is a Java Champion, Web Developer, and Developer Advocate at Okta. He loves to architect and build APIs and slick-looking UIs using CSS + JavaScript. When he's not evangelizing Okta and open source, he likes to ski with his family, drive his VWs and enjoy craft beer. You can find him on Twitter @mraible or on his website at https://raibledesigns.com.

• Parking

Visitor parking at the Google building is located in front of the towers. Entrance is off of Pearl Street, just before Chase bank. There are only about 10-15 spots.

events.name: SEO: Gaming Google at Google? Tips from an Outsider
events.description:
Embark on my SEO Journey as I take you through the evolution of SEO (since early 2000’s), discuss major Google Algorithm Updates (Panda, Penguin, Hummingbird etc.) and attempt to distill Google’s 200+ search ranking factors. I’ll also cover Google local, national and international SEO. This is by no means a spill the beans on Google or divulge Google’s secret sauce.. since no one can crack the code (it’s Google after all), I’ll share white hat best practices accumulated from doing SEO since 1999.

• Parking

Visitor parking at the Google building is located in front of the towers. Entrance is off of Pearl Street, just before Chase bank. There are only about 10-15 spots.

You should also be able to park in the Chase parking lot since the event is after hours and they will be closed. Otherwise, you can park in the shopping center across the street and walk over.

• Security

Make sure you answer the question for "First name & last name" so we can print you a badge to enter the Google building.

events.name: Flutter: Finally, a Cross-platform Development Framework for Mobile Devs
events.description:
Come with me and you'll be in a world of pure desegregation. Let's discuss the pros and cons of Flutter and why Mobile Developers should take a serious look into the framework. We'll include comparisons to existing cross-platform frameworks, performance analysis, and a bit of live coding to show just how fast development can be. I'll share tales of my personal experience with Flutter, and how I'm passively making all of my co-workers hate me.

• Parking

Visitor parking at the Google building is located in front of the towers. Entrance is off of Pearl Street, just before Chase bank. There are only about 10-15 spots. Do not park in the Chase bank parking lot.

Additional visitor parking is available in the Google underground garage. Entrance is behind the Google buildings off 30th Street. events.name: GDG NoCo: Build Actions for Your Community Kick Off Event Party
events.description:

https://www.meetup.com/GDGNoCo/events/251081374/

Join us and participate in a Hackathon to Build Actions for the Community for the Google Assistant. Bring laptops and I will show you how to get started with new Codelabs, code resources and examples. Do you have a great idea for an Assistant App? You may choose to sign up for the hackathon or just join us to socialize and learn more about making Actions for the Google Assistant. No formal code experience is required to build a great app for the Google Assistant, which makes this a fun hackathon for all levels of experience. Let's explore what's new with Dialogflow as of I/O '18 and build some apps! There will be prizes for the hackathon. Winners will be announced and prizes handed out at Part Two of this series, one week from this meetup.

RSVP at https://www.meetup.com/GDGNoCo/events/251079904/ and https://www.meetup.com/GDGNoCo/events/251081374/

events.name: A Tour of TensorFlow’s APIs
events.description:
Dean Wyatte is a Lead Data Scientist at Activision where he researches and develops and machine learning systems for online games. He has previously worked in machine learning for cybersecurity applications and for mobile devices. He received his PhD from the University of Colorado Boulder where he studied biological neural networks for visual recognition and temporal sequence learning.

TensorFlow makes a number of different APIs available to users. Many users are probably familiar with the low-level API in which graphs and sessions must be explicitly managed by the user or Keras, which abstracts over these details allowing the user to focus on designing machine learning models. In this talk, Dean will discuss some of TensorFlow’s recently added high-level APIs, which include the Dataset and Estimator constructs. These constructs provide a number of benefits to users such as input pipelining and distributed training with minimal code changes

Parking

Visitor parking at the Google building is located in front of the towers. Entrance is off of Pearl Street, just before Chase bank. There are only about 10-15 spots. Do not park in the Chase bank parking lot.

Additional visitor parking is available in the Google underground garage. Entrance is behind the Google buildings off 30th Street. events.name: DevFest Fairgrounds
events.description:
~ Joint event with GDG Northern Colorado ~

Come to DevFest Fairgrounds for a fun day of hands-on coding to learn some cool new Google tech!

We'll start the day with a 15-minute talk on each of our three topics: TensorFlow, Google Actions and Flutter.

9:00 AM Welcome
9:05 AM Introduction to TensorFlow
9:20 AM Introduction to Google Actions
9:35 AM Introduction to Flutter
9:50 AM Break

Then we'll start coding! There will be booths for each of the topics where you can sit down and go through a codelab or work on your own project, with people around you to help.

We'll do pomodoro-style rotation, where you code for 45 minutes and then take a 15 minutes break. There will carnival games set up so those breaks are going to be fun!

events.name: Machine Learning for Mobile with TensorFlow
events.description:
Our speaker will be presenting remotely via Google Hangout.

TALK ABSTRACT
----------------------
Are you interested in getting started with machine learning, and making intelligent apps with the most popular deep learning framework TensorFlow? Come to this talk to learn your various options: from using ready made APIs to training your own custom models. You will learn the end to end process of how to train a model with TensorFlow high level API tf.Keras, convert to a TensorFlow Lite model and deploy it to an Android app.

Topics covered in this talk:
- Intro to deep learning, TensorFlow and TensorFlow Lite
- Transfer learning using pre-trained ConvNets
- Train a model from scratch and deploy it to Android for inference

SLIDES
----------
bit.ly/ml-for-mobile-with-tf

ABOUT THE SPEAKER
-----------------------------
Margaret Maynard-Reid is a Google Developer Expert(GDE) for Machine Learning, and she develops Android apps with intelligence. She leads GDG Seattle and co-organizes Seattle Data/Analytics/Machine Learning meetup groups. She writes blogs and speaks at conferences on TensorFlow, deep learning and Android. She is passionate about community building and helping others get into Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning.

Twitter handle @margaretmz (https://twitter.com/margaretmz)

PARKING
------------
Visitor parking at the Google building is located in front of the towers. Entrance is off of Pearl Street, just before Chase bank. There are only about 10-15 spots. Do not park in the Chase bank parking lot.

Additional visitor parking is available in the Google underground garage. Entrance is behind the Google buildings off 30th Street. Use the intercom, tell the attendant you are there for the GDG Boulder Meetup, and they will open the gate. Take the Building B elevator (closest to the entrance) to Floor 1.

events.description:

----------------------

events.name: Kotlin/Everywhere: Introduction to Kotlin
events.description:
Android development is moving towards Kotlin, which has many awesome features. But it can be overwhelming to learn yet another language!

Christine Kennedy is going to highlight some Kotlin language features you are most likely to encounter in Android. The goal is to help you understand Kotlin code you see in documentation, tutorials and talks so you can pick up the Android concepts they demonstrate.

If you are attending https://360andev.com in July, this will help you understand the slides as they are mostly going to be in Kotlin.

This event is a part of the Kotlin/Everywhere series: https://kotl.in/everywhere

events.name: A.I. for Artists
events.description:
Artificial Intelligence has been a hot topic recently. From process automation, to self-driving cars, every industry seems to want a bite of this tasty new trend in computer science. But what does it mean for creatives? My name is Chris Hutt, and I’d like to share with you a few tools that will take some of the mystery out of A.I. and hopefully empower your artistic process.

Data Scientists and Programmers may find something useful in this discussion, but so too will Designers, Poets, and Painters. No programming experience is required, but if you have a laptop you might want to bring it along.

events.name: Flutter for Web and Other News in the Flutter and Dart Ecosystem
events.description:
You might know Flutter as Google's UI toolkit for building cross-platform mobile apps. But it's also coming to the web. In fact, it's already here. Google just announced that the developer preview for Flutter for Web is now just a part of Flutter. Which means Flutter should be ready for production use on the web, right? It's still early days. Is it really ready for prime time? In this talk we'll discuss the good and the not so good of using Flutter for your website. We'll also discuss the progress Flutter and Dart have made in general throughout the year.

Agenda
=====

8:00 PM Mingle
8:15 PM Doors Close

answers.question: What do you want to see from GDG Boulder?
What interests you most about developing for Google Platforms?
What advancement in technology are you most looking forward to?

group_profile.intro: Android GDE. I blog and speak about Android: http://blog.sqisland.com http://chiuki.github.io

answers.question: What do you want to see from GDG Boulder?
answers.answer: I'd like to see what all the fantastic minds here in Boulder can come up with.

answers.question: What interests you most about developing for Google Platforms?
answers.answer: I'm interested in how analytics and Google Applications for the public sector can improve government services, promote transparency, and instill more efficient practices.

answers.question: What advancement in technology are you most looking forward to?
answers.answer: An integrated, transnational analytics framework dedicated to accurately monitoring the world's water resources.

group_profile.intro: I'm C.T. Hutt, a manager for GDG Boulder. I'm a former government analyst from D.C. with a background in analytics and marketing. I've been in Boulder for about four years
